content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and efficiency. Eligible projects aim to mitigate traffic congestion, reduce emissions, save energy, and enhance railroad operations. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving rail-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and maintaining track structures. Funding is not provided for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or construction of maintenance and passenger facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20 percent of project costs funded under this title from non-Federal sources. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. Additional discretionary amounts are at the Secretary's discretion. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. The Secretary also uses 20% of the grant amount for projects of national significance with emphasis on those with the greatest public benefit. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation ensures that workers on funded projects are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. At least 10% of funds must go to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. The term "rail miles" refers to route miles, not track miles. The term "railroad" includes freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation as part of the general rail system. The tax imposed on specified railroad equipment is 5% of the sale price. Specified equipment includes locomotives and other rolling stock. Regulations allow for the separate purchase and installation of parts and accessories within 6 months of the equipment being placed in service. The tax imposed on specified railroad equipment is 5% of the sale price. Parts or accessories installed within 6 months of equipment being placed in service are subject to a 5% tax, with installers being secondarily liable. Exceptions apply for replacement parts or accessories. SEC. 202. TAX ON RAIL TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS OR PROPERTY. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on October 1, 2003. Chapter 33 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subchapter on Transportation by Rail, covering the transportation of persons and property, along with definitions and special rules. The tax on rail transportation of persons is imposed at 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases. The tax is paid by the person making the payment. The tax on rail transportation of property is imposed at 1% of the amount paid for such transportation. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except in cases where payments are made outside the United States. In such cases, the tax is paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States. The tax on rail transportation of property in the United States is paid by the person receiving the property and collected by the person providing the last segment of the transportation. SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. The term "transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders and tax deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. The tax rules for taxable rail transportation include deductions from refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment and payment of any uncollected tax by the carrier. The tax rules for taxable rail transportation include deductions from refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment and payment of any uncollected tax by the carrier. A carrier providing the initial segment of such transportation in the United States is subject to these rules. The amendments for transportation by rail will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new section, SEC. 9511, is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes related to trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund receives funding from various sources, including royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund, funded by royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands, is designated for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
